{{EngvarB|date=July 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} [[File:MTN logo.png|thumb|MTN logo]] MTN Group, a major multi-national telecom company based in [[Johannesburg]], [[South Africa]], was handed down a $5.2 billion [[Fine (penalty)|fine]] by the [[Federal Government of Nigeria]] through the [[Nigerian Communications Commission]] (NCC). The commission exercised section 20(1) of the Telephone Subscribers regulation (TSR) law on MTN, for not meeting the deadline set up by the [[Mobile network operator]]s (MNOs) for disconnecting the Subscribers Identification Modules (SIM) with improper registration. The [[Quality audit|compliance audit]] carried out by the NCC on MTN network revealed unregistered 5.2 million customers lines un-deactivated. This led to the NCC fining MTN with the sum of $1000 for each unregistered SIM, which amounted to $5.2bn.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ngrguardiannews.com/2015/10/mtn-in-talks-with-ncc-over-n1-04tr-fine-on-telecoms-firm/|title=MTN in talks with NCC over N1.04tr fine on telecoms firm|work=Guardian Newspaper |author=Adeyemi Adepetun|accessdate=27 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thisdaylive.com/articles/mtn-ceo-dabengwa-resigns-after-5-2bn-nigeria-fine/225138/|title=MTN CEO Dabengwa Resigns After $5.2bn Nigeria Fine|work=Thisday Live|accessdate=28 December 2015}}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
What followed was major resignations among the top echelon of the organisation including the chief executive officer, Sifiso Dabengwa, the Head of Nigeria Operation, Micheal Ikpoki and the Head of Cooperate Affairs, Akinwale Goodluck being replaced with Phuthuma Nhleko, Ferdi Moolman and Amina Oyegbola as new chairman, managing director and Head of Corporate and Regulation respectively.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ngrguardiannews.com/2015/12/mtn-nigeria-ceo-resigns-as-fg-slashes-fine-to-n674b/|title=MTN Nigeria CEO resigns as FG slashes fine to N674b|work=Guardian Newspaper|author=Tonye Bakare|accessdate=27 December 2015}}</ref>
The new management employed a diplomatic measure between the government of the [[South Africa|Republic of South Africa]] and its Nigerian counterpart to ameliorate the burden of the liabilities from the fine. This action brought about the reduction of the liability to $3.2 billion.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thisdaylive.com/articles/mtn-shares-plummet-for-second-day-on-ncc-fine/223958/|title=MTN Shares Plummet for Second Day on NCC Fine|work=THIS DAY LIVE|author=Emma Okonji|accessdate=26 December 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151030203840/http://www.thisdaylive.com/articles/mtn-shares-plummet-for-second-day-on-ncc-fine/223958|archivedate=30 October 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.bbc.com/news/business-34696777|title=MTN seeks to reduce $5.2bn Nigerian fine|work=bbc news|accessdate=27 December 2015}}</ref>
The registration of SIM cards started in the year 2010, the initial phase of this project was handled by the Mobile Network Operators (MNOs). However, NCC took over these operations because the service providers could not meet up with the six months earmarked by NCC. The registration by NCC started in March 2011 and it was anchored by seven consultants.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ngrguardiannews.com/2015/08/mtn-claims-n10b-expenses-on-sim-registration/|title=MTN claims N10b expenses on SIM registration|work=Guardian Newspaper|author=Adeyemi Adepetun|accessdate=27 December 2015}}</ref>
==Activities that led to the penalty ==
In 2010 the Nigerian government through the [[National Security Advisor (Nigeria)|National Security Adviser]], other securities agencies and the NCC initiated that all SIM-cards across all mobile networks in the country should be registered. The primary objective of this project is to reduce security challenges facing the country by criminals using mobile phones to perpetuate kidnapping, robbery and other criminal activities. This exercise is in line with Section 20(1) of Registration of Telephone Subscribers Regulations (TSR) 2011 which states that: "Any licensee who activates or fails to deactivate a subscription medium in violation of any provision of these Regulations is liable to a penalty of N200,000.00 for each unregistered but activated subscription medium." <ref name="Odunsi">{{cite web|url=http://dailypost.ng/2015/11/17/mtn-ncc-gives-full-explanation-on-n1trn-fine-sets-friday-deadline/|title=MTN: NCC gives full explanation on N1trn fine, sets Friday deadline|work=Daily Post|author=Wale Odunsi|accessdate=28 December 2015}}</ref>
In 2011, following the regulation the NCC directed all MNOs to deactivate newly registered lines that remain inactive for 48 hours after registration. In August 2015, NCC and securities agencies carried out a compliance audit on all of the MNOs networks. Contrary to the TSR, the audit revealed 5.2 million customer lines in MTN were improperly registered. [[Sahara Reporters]] claimed that the NCC and security agencies informed the public during a press conference held on 18 August 2015, that the expiration of the 7-day deactivation deadline ends on 11 August 2015. MTN failed to fully deactivate any subscribers and following repeated warnings and compliance enforcement visits by the responsible authorities only made a partial attempt to bar unregistered subscribers in selected areas over a few days in September 2015. Other operators had fully complied and reconciled their deactivations with the invalid registrations shared by the NCC up to 4 weeks earlier. The consequence of MTN's refusal to comply with the directive is even more pronounced as half of all the invalid registrations shared by the NCC belongs to MTN.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://saharareporters.com/2015/10/27/how-big-and-rich-mtn-walked-outlaw-path-52bn-fine-nigeria|title=How Big And Rich MTN Walked The Outlaw Path Into $5.2bn Fine in Nigeria|work=Sahara Reporter|accessdate=27 December 2015}}</ref>
In a related development, the [[House of Representatives (Nigeria)|house of representatives]] committee on telecommunications, headed by Saheed Akinade Fijabi to investigate the abuse among the MNOs in complying with the registration of SIM cards in the country.<ref name="MTN">{{cite web|url= http://www.ngrguardiannews.com/2015/10/mtn-gets-deadline-to-pay-n1-04-trillion-fine/|title=MTN gets deadline to pay N1.04 trillion fine|work=Guardian Newspaper|author=Adeyemi Adepetun|accessdate=27 December 2015}}</ref>
In a letter addressed to NCC on 2 November 2015, MTN admitted wrongdoing for their role of 5.2 million improperly registered SIMs after the NCC deadline on the network and also pleaded for mercy. NCC acknowledged the letter from MTN, but said the decision on the penalty is final, but the deadline for payment could be shifted to accommodate the position of each party.<ref name="Odunsi" />
==Post penalty activities==
In October 2015, NCC made the pronouncement to penalise MTN for their inability to disconnect 5.2 million unregistered subscribers on its network. According to the TSR signed by all stakeholders in the telecommunications industry, any erring MNO shall be charged with N200,000 or $1000 per unregistered SIM on their network after the deadline for the registration. Subsequently, the commission demanded the sum of $5.2billion being the total amount payable by MTN for their role in improper SIM registration, to be paid on or before 16 November 2015. In a swift move to pacify its shareholders, MTN published a press release on the same day of the pronouncement that the deadline for the payment of the penalty fee of the $5.2bn (16 November 2015) will not be effected by the commission until the end of the negotiation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nigeriannewspapers.today/2015/11/16/nigeria-extends-mtns-5-2bn-fine-payment/|title=Nigeria extends MTN's $5.2bn fine payment|work=Guardian Newspaper|accessdate=28 December 2015}}</ref> As part of the strategy to re-stabilize the organisation, Phuthuma Nhleko, was appointed in temporary capacity as the Chairman of the organisation over the next 6 months. This action follows the resignation of Sifiso Dabengwa, the CEO of the organisation. Dabengwa in a letter confessed to [[The Guardian (Nigeria)|Guardian Newspaper]] that "Due to the most unfortunate prevailing circumstances occurring at MTN Nigeria, I, in the interest of the company and its shareholders, have tendered my resignation with immediate effect.".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ngrguardiannews.com/2015/11/5-2b-fine-mtns-ceo-quits/|title=$5.2b fine: MTN’s CEO quits|work=Guardian Newspaper|author=Adeyemi Adepetun, Chijioke Nelson|accessdate=28 December 2015}}</ref> The office of the presidency in Nigeria took over the case of improper SIM registration. This instance warranted MTN group to organise a diplomatic meeting between president [[Jacob Zuma]] of South African and its Nigerian counterpart [[Muhammadu Buhari]]. The outcome of this meeting is the reduction of the fee from $5.2bn to $3.2bn.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.techcentral.co.za/zuma-buhari-said-to-meet-over-mtn/61685/|title=Zuma, Buhari said to meet over MTN|work=Technical Central|accessdate=29 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thecable.ng/ncc-cuts-mtn-fine-by-n360bn|title=NCC reduces MTN's N1.04trn fine to N674bn|work=The Cable|author=Muyiwa Tijani|accessdate=29 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://leadership.ng/news/479131/pmb-zuma-meet-mtns-n1-04trn-fine|title=PMB, Zuma To Meet Over MTN's N1.04trn Fine|work=Leadership|author=Ebriku John Friday}}</ref> In a related development, many Nigerians are unhappy and took the case to a court of law for proper interpretation of the position taking by the government. A group of concerned Nigerian based in Abuja, said the action taking by the FGN is a slap on the fundamental human right and breach of our Nigeria constitutions. Timipa Okponipere, the lawyer to the applicant believe the action is not only a breached of Nigeria Constitution but an attempt by NCC to conspire with MTN to cheat Nigerians of our common wealth. He said, if the decision is not pursue to a logical end it would amount to mere academic exercise.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.premiumtimesng.com/news/more-news/194801-nigerians-sue-ncc-for-reducing-mtns-n1-04-trn-fine.html|title=Nigerians sue NCC for reducing MTN's N1.04 trn fine|work=Premium times|author=Bassey Udo|accessdate=2 February 2016}}</ref>
Following the report of the slash in the penalty fee, MTN Nigeria head to court challenging the 20% reduction on the ground that the amount will diminish their profit.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thisdaylive.com/articles/mtn-heads-to-court-over-3-9bn-fine/228278/|title=MTN Heads to Court over $3.9bn Fine|work=Thisday live|author=Emma Okonji|accessdate=28 December 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151221021411/http://www.thisdaylive.com/articles/mtn-heads-to-court-over-3-9bn-fine/228278|archivedate=21 December 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thisdaylive.com/articles/lawyer-calls-for-caution-over-nccs-n1-04trn-fine-of-mtn/224044/|title=Lawyer Calls for Caution over NCC's N1.04trn Fine of MTN|work=Thisday Live|author=Emma Okonkji|accessdate=28 December 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151031152645/http://www.thisdaylive.com/articles/lawyer-calls-for-caution-over-nccs-n1-04trn-fine-of-mtn/224044|archivedate=31 October 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> According to the [[Mail & Guardian]], John Burke, director of issuer regulation at the JSE said: "The JSE has halted all trading on MTN Group Limited. Trading will resume as soon as MTN Group Limited has issued a Sens announcement." Subsequently, 14% loss was declared on the market value of the company by [[JSE Limited|Johannesburg Stock Exchange]] (JSE).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mg.co.za/article/2015-11-02-jse-suspends-trade-of-jse-stocks|title=JSE suspends trade of MTN stocks|work=Mail&Guardian|author=Lisa Steyn|accessdate=28 December 2015}}</ref> In another fresh development, the Nigerian Governors Forum, an association of 36 governors from all the states in the federation. In a statement signed by the chairman declared their support to the NCC for penalising MTN for not disconnecting 5.2 million unregistered subscribers on their database, after the deadline given by the commission. The Chairman of the forum said "The forum also commended the NCC for its strict compliance and enforcement of the law with regards to the fine issued to MTN and advised the federal government to ensure prompt and full payment."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.communicationstoday.co.in/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=17090&Itemid=147|title=Nigeria's Governors Back Telecom Regulator's USD 5.2 Billion MTN Fine|work=Telecoms and Networking Communication Today|author=Alexis Akwagyiram|accessdate=1 January 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303123851/http://www.communicationstoday.co.in/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=17090&Itemid=147|archivedate=3 March 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.enca.com/africa/mtn-held-fine-payment-deadline-nigeria-0|title=MTN held to fine-payment deadline in Nigeria|work=eNCA|accessdate=1 January 2015}}</ref>
==The deadline for the penalty expires==
The federal government of Nigeria after deliberations with the management team of MTN, gave 31 December 2015 as the last day for the payment of the penalty fee. According to the spokesperson of NCC, Tony Ojobo, the commission decision on this issue remains unchanged.
On 17 December 2015, MTN announced their decision to contest the decision by the FGN enforcing the payment of the penalty on the last day of the year 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thisdaylive.com/articles/mtn-fine-ncc-says-today-s-deadline-remains/229199/|title=MTN Fine: NCC Says Today’s Deadline Remains|work=Thisday live|author=Emma Okonji|accessdate=2 January 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160105051202/http://www.thisdaylive.com/articles/mtn-fine-ncc-says-today-s-deadline-remains/229199/|archivedate=5 January 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
MTN Nigeria also got an order from the Federal high Court stopping the Federal Government from preventing MTN Nigeria from moving its funds in [[Banking in Nigeria|Nigerian Banks]] out of the country.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.punchng.com/n1tn-fine-court-rejects-application-to-seize-mtns-funds/6|title=N1tn fine: Court rejects application to seize MTN’s funds|work=Punch|author=Ramon Oladimeji|accessdate=13 January 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160205021030/http://www.punchng.com/n1tn-fine-court-rejects-application-to-seize-mtns-funds/6/|archivedate=5 February 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
It was announced on 22 January 2016 that MTN would have until 18 March of the same year to reach an out of court settlement.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Telecoms: Shares jump as South Africa's MTN aims to settle Nigerian fine out of court {{!}} West Africa|url = http://www.theafricareport.com/West-Africa/telecoms-shares-jump-as-south-africas-mtn-aims-to-settle-nigerian-fine-out-of-court.html|website = www.theafricareport.com|access-date = 25 January 2016|first = Jun|last = Feng}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://leadership.ng/business/494403/mtn-gets-two-months-extension-pay-ncc-fine|title=MTN Gets Two Months Extension To Pay NCC Fine|work=LEADERSHIP|accessdate=2 February 2016}}</ref>
==MTN engages ex US attorney general==
MTN has engaged the service of Mr. [[Eric Holder]], a former US attorney general to intervene in the ongoing slam of $5.2bn fine on the telecommunications company, which was subsequently reduces to $3.9 by the Nigerian government through NCC after much persuasion. He was hired by the MTN group because of his experience in corporate settlement.He served as US attorney general between the year 2009–2015. According to report by [[Financial Times]] Holder visited [[Abuja]], the [[federal capital territory]], Nigeria in January 2016 to meet with the official of NCC to challenge the fine.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/1022636e-c991-11e5-be0b-b7ece4e953a0.html#axzz3zB7DAM3P|title=MTN hires ex-US attorney-general Eric Holder to fight $3.9bn fine|author=William Wals & Andrew England|work=Financial Times|accessdate=4 February 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://dailypost.ng/2016/02/03/3-9b-fine-mtn-hires-ex-u-s-attorney-general-to-challenge-ncc/|title=$3.9b fine: MTN hires ex-U.S attorney general to challenge NCC|author=Daniel Ogbeche|work=Daily post|accessdate=4 February 2016}}</ref>
==FG sets condition for out-of-court settlement==
The FGN through the minister of communication, Mr. [[Abdur-Raheem Adebayo Shittu|Adebayo Shittu]] on 26 January 2016, gave conditions to be met by MTN before FGN can agree to out-of-court settlement of the litigation made against the government by the communication firm. The case remains in court as at this date( February 2016). The minister requested that the case can be settled as per MTN request only if the communication firm withdraw the case from court and also if the president, [[Muhammadu Buhari]] approves a new deal for settlement. The minister said "As far as we are concerned, there can be no out-of-court settlement except the case is withdrawn from the court so that the government will not be put under pressure. If the case is out of court and if they make further moves, Mr. President may graciously make a decision. But now, I am not aware of any out-of-court settlement talks.".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.punchng.com/fg-gives-conditions-for-out-of-court-settlement-with-mtn/|title=FG gives conditions for out-of-court settlement with MTN|author=Everest Amaefule|work=The Punch News|accessdate=9 February 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160216180246/http://www.punchng.com/fg-gives-conditions-for-out-of-court-settlement-with-mtn/|archivedate=16 February 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In another development, it was reported that the FGN is not ready to shift ground for the out-of-court settlement by MTN. The minister said "We are not aware of any out of court settlement on the issue. We will not accept out of court settlement until MTN willingly discontinue the case".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://givenbiznews.com/3-4bn-fine-well-not-accept-mtns-out-of-court-settlement-offer-fg/|title=3.4bn fine we'll not accept mtns out of court settlement offer-FG|work=Givenbiznews|accessdate=9 February 2016}}</ref>
==MTN pays advance $250 million dollars==
On 24 February 2016, MTN announced the payment of $250 million as an advance-payment towards a reduced settlement, yet to be finalised, of the imposed penalty by the FGN. MTN group, through their spokesperson, said, "Pursuant to the ongoing engagement with the Nigerian authorities, MTN Nigeria has today (yesterday), made an agreed payment of N50 billion ($250 million) to the Federal Government of Nigeria on the basis that this will be applied towards a settlement, where one is eventually, and hopefully, arrived at. In an effort to achieve an amicable settlement, MTN has agreed to withdraw the matter from the Federal High Court in Lagos. Phuthuma Nhleko in his capacity as executive chairman of MTN Group and a director of MTN Nigeria is continuing to lead the team engaging the Nigerian authorities with a view to settling the matter."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.leadership.ng/news/504247/3-4bn-fine-mtn-pays-initial-250m-withdraws-court-case|title=$3.4bn Fine: MTN Pays Initial $250m, Withdraws Court Case|work=Chima Akwaja|author=The Leadership|accessdate=25 February 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://thenewsnigeria.com.ng/2016/02/3-9bn-fine-mtn-pays-250m-to-nigeria-withdraws-suit/|title=3.9bn fine MTN pays 250m to Nigeria withdraws suit|work=The News|accessdate=25 February 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/fastft/2016/02/24/mtn-pays-nigeria-250m-to-further-fine-talks/|title=mtn pays nigeria 250m to further fine talk|work=Financial Times|accessdate=25 February 2016}}</ref> In the same development, the MTN Nigeria Chief Executive Office (CEO), Ferdi Moolman, said the firm has withdrawn the case in the federal high court in the intent to further deliberate on the settlement of the fine<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.premiumtimesng.com/business/business-news/198979-mtn-drops-lawsuit-nigeria-pays-250m-towards-possible-settlement.html|title=MTN drops lawsuit against Nigeria, pays $250m toward possible settlement|work=The Prime News|accessdate=25 February 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vanguardngr.com/2016/02/mtn-drops-lawsuit-against-nigeria-pays-250m-toward-possible-settlement/|title=TN drops drops law suit Nigeria pays 250M towards possible settlement|work=The Vanguard|accessdate=25 February 2016}}</ref>
==Nigeria president speaks on MTN Fine== On 8 March 2016, President Mohammadu Buhari (PMB) hosted [[Jacob Zuma]], the president of the South Africa Republic (RSA), on an official visit. During the visit, PMB noted that the negligence of MTN to follow the NCC mandate to de-register unapproved SIMs had aided the activities of terrorists in the country. He said "The concern of the Federal Government was basically on the security and not the fine imposed on MTN. “You know how the unregistered GSM (SIM cards) are being used by terrorists and between 2009 and today, at least 10,000 Nigerians were killed by Boko Haram, at least 10,000".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.punchng.com/5-2bn-fine-mtns-inaction-aided-boko-haram-says-buhari/|title=$5.2bn fine: MTN’s inaction aided Boko Haram, says Buhari|work=The Punch news paper|author=Olalekan Adetayo|accessdate=11 March 2016}}</ref>
==MTN withdraws case suits against NCC and Nigeria== Chief [[Wole Olanipekun]], the counsel to the telecommunication company, announced on Friday 18 March 2016 the withdrawal of suits instituted against NCC and the FGN contesting the fine slammed on it for its failure to disconnect unregistered SIMs from its network.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.punchng.com/n1-04tn-fine-mtn-withdraws-suit-ncc-agf/|title=N1.04tn fine: MTN withdraws suit against NCC, AGF|work=The Punch|author=Ramon Oladimeji|accessdate=20 March 2016}}</ref>
==MTN finalise payment plan with NCC== On 10 June 2016, MTN announced through its chief executive officer, [[Ferdi Moolman]], that the sum of N300bn (less than $1 billion) had been accepted as the final settlement of the fine demanded by FG for not disconnecting unregistered lines from its network by the deadline giving by NCC to all MTOs in the country. The reduced fine must be paid within a period of three years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thisdaylive.com/index.php/2016/06/12/why-mtn-will-rebound-after-n330-billion-fine/|title=Why MTN Will Rebound after N330 Billion Fine|work=This Day|author=Kunle Aderinokun|accessdate=13 June 2016}}</ref> The telecommunication company also promised to list its [[stock]] on the [[Nigeria Stock Exchange]]. According to [[Premium Times]], Ferdi said that "MTN will pay the NCC the sum of N330 billion in full and final settlement of the fine in line with an agreed payment plan,".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.premiumtimesng.com/news/headlines/205073-n1-04-trillion-fine-mtn-announces-final-agreement-nigeria.html|title=N1.04 trillion Fine: MTN announces final agreement with Nigeria|work=Premium Times|author=Bassey Edo|accessdate=13 June 2016}}</ref> In line with the agreement, the last tranche of the bill will be paid on 31 May 2019.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vanguardngr.com/2016/06/n1-04trn-fine-fg-reduces-mtn-fine-agrees-staggered-payment-option/|title=N1.04trn fine: FG reduces MTN fine, agrees staggered payment option|work=Vanguard|author=Prince Osuagwu,Johnbosco Agbakwuru & Emmannuel Elebeke|accessdate=13 June 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.punchng.com/telecoms-giant-mtn-agrees-pay-nigerian-1-7-billion-fine/|title=BREAKING: MTN agrees to pay $1.7bn fine|work=Punch|accessdate=13 June 2016}}</ref>
===MTN paid first installment=== The minister of communication in Nigeria, Adebayo Shittu, confirmed the payment of $254 million, the first tranche of the three-installments settlement plan.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Samson|first1=Omale|title=MTN makes first payment of $254m in Nigeria fine|url=http://ewn.co.za/2016/12/27/mtn-makes-first-payment-of-usd254m-in-nigeria-fine|website=Eye Witness News|accessdate=27 December 2016}}</ref> The fine of $5.2 billion was reduced to $1.7 billion. According to [[africanews]], "For the first year, they paid N80 billion, after paying the initial N50 billion, and they will have to pay for three years until they will complete the N330 billion".<ref>{{cite web|title=MTN Resolves Nigerian Phone Dispute With $1.7 Billion Deal|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-06-10/mtn-agrees-to-pay-1-7-billion-nigeria-fine-over-three-years|website=Bloomberg.com|date=10 June 2016}}</ref>
=== MTN pays additional 30 billion Naira=== The telecommunication company recently paid additional 30 billion Naira to offset part of the initial fine of 330 billion Naira fined.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Odunsi|first1=Wale|title=MTN pays additional N30bn fine to Nigerian government|url=http://dailypost.ng/2017/03/31/mtn-pays-additional-n30bn-fine-nigerian-government/|publisher=Daily Post|accessdate=26 April 2017}}</ref>

'''Measurement-assisted assembly''' ('''MAA''')<ref>Kayani, A. and J. Jamshidi. Measurement Assisted Assembly For Large Volume Aircraft Wing Structures. in 4th International Conference on Digital Enterprise Technology. 2007. Bath, United Kingdom. p. 426-434</ref> is any method of assembly in which measurements are used to guide assembly processes. Such processes include: * '''Predictive fettling/shimming'''<ref>Kayani, A. and I. Gray, Shim for Arrangement Against a Structural Component and a Method of Making a Shim. 2009, Patent US20080211185 20080916, Airbus UK Ltd</ref> in which component measurements are used to predict gaps and interferences prior to assembly, and these predictions are used to enable a right-first-time assembly * '''Assemble-Measure-Move''' ('''AMM''')<ref>Muelaner, J.E., A. Kayani, O. Martin, and P.G. Maropoulos. Measurement Assisted Assembly and the Roadmap to Part-To-Part Assembly. in 7th International Conference on Digital Enterprise Technology. 2011. Athens, Greece, Available from http://www.muelaner.com/research/MADA/MAA_and_Roadmap_to_Part-To-Part.html</ref> processes where a component is positioned approximately in an assembly, the position of the component is measured and then it is moved towards its specified position. This process may be iterated a number of times before the component is within its specified position, alternatively 'real time' measurements may be used to 'track' the component into location. * '''Active tooling''' is a form of [[Fixture (tool)|assembly fixture]] which does not rely on inherent dimensional stability to provide an accurate location for components but rather uses frequent measurements to facilitate in active compensation. * '''[[Control theory|Closed loop control]]''' of assembly automation in order to improve the accuracy of flexible automation systems such as [[industrial robots]].<ref>Summers, M., Robot Capability Test and Development of Industrial Robot Positioning System for the Aerospace Industry, in AeroTech Congress & Exhibition. 2005, SAE International: Grapevine,Texas. p. 1-13</ref> Measurement-assisted assembly is typically used for large structures such as [[Airframe|aircraft]] and [[Fabrication (metal)|steel fabrications]]. It can be used to improve production rates, reduce reworking and increase flexibility for processes where manual reworking during assembly is required to maintain assembly form and component interface conditions. This type of approach generally offers no advantages where [[Interchangeable parts|part-to-part interchangeability]] can already be achieved.

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} {{peacock|date=March 2017}} {{Infobox person |name = Menaye Donkor |image = |caption = |birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1981|3|20}} |birth_place = [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], Canada |nationality = [[Canadians|Canadian]] |other_names = Menaye Donkor Muntari |citizenship = [[Canadian nationality law|Canada]] and [[Ghanaian nationality law|Ghana]] |education = [[Marketing]], [[Business marketing]] |alma_mater = [[York University]]
([[Bachelor of Business Administration|BBA]]) |occupation = [[businesswoman]], [[Model (person)|model]], [[entrepreneur]], [[philanthropist]] |known_for = [[Miss Universe]], 2004
[[Miss Universe Ghana]], 2004 |height_cm = 180 |spouse = {{marriage|[[Sulley Muntari]]|2010}} |children = Jamal Krasie Muntari |awards = |website = [http://www.menaye.org/ www.menaye.org] }} '''Menaye Donkor''' (born 20 March 1981) is a Canadian-born Ghanaian businesswoman, entrepreneur, philanthropist, and former beauty queen who was named Miss Universe Ghana 2004,{{cite web | url =http://allafricafashion.com/philanthropist-model-and-former-miss-universe-ghana-menaye-donkor-muntari-announced-as-afwl-2012-ambassador/ | title = Philanthropist, model and former Miss Universe Ghana, Menaye Donkor Muntari announced as AFWL 2012 ambassador | accessdate =30 July 2012 | publisher =allafricafashion.com}} and represented [[Ghana]] in [[Miss Universe 2004]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ghanasoccernet.com/menaye-donkor-not-your-average-footballer%E2%80%99s-wife/|title=Menaye Donkor: Not Your Average Footballer’s Wife|publisher=Ghanasoccernet.com|accessdate=30 July 2012}} Donkor is the wife of [[Ghana]]ian professional footballer [[Sulley Muntari]].{{cite web|url=http://nicoldenoir.blogspot.com/2012/04/new-african-woman-magazine-with-menaye.html|title=Menaye Donkor: Who's that girl?|publisher=Africasia.com|accessdate=30 July 2012}} ==Early life== Menaye Donkor was brought up by her parents in [[Accra]], Ghana, and is the youngest of seven siblings with four brothers and two sisters. At the age of seven she inherited the job title of "Royal Stool Bearer" for her paternal grandmother, who is the Queen mother of Agona Asafo.{{Cite web|url=https://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/entertainment/I-m-a-true-African-woman-Menaye-Donkor-235001|title=I’m a true African woman-Menaye Donkor|website=www.ghanaweb.com|language=en|access-date=29 September 2017}} Donkor received her childhood education in [[Ghana]], lived and studied in [[Boston]], [[Massachusetts]], USA, during her high school years, and moved back to her birthplace in [[Toronto]] to study [[marketing]] and [[business marketing]] at [[York University]], where she graduated with honours. In the summer of 2011, she studied film at The Studio (formerly The Sally Johnson Studio) in [[New York City]] and then completed a film course with [[Brian Deacon]] at the London Academy of Film, Media and Television. ==Career== In her early twenties Menaye Donkor won the title [[Miss Universe Ghana]],{{Cite web|url=https://ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/entertainment/Muntari-pushed-me-to-Miss-Universe-Ghana-Menaye-580913|title=Muntari pushed me to Miss Universe Ghana — Menaye|website=ghanaweb.com|language=en|access-date=29 September 2017}} and spent a few years travelling the world, working as a model. She appeared on the covers of many magazines in [[Ghana]], [[South Africa]] and [[Italy]] such as ''New African Woman'', ''Pompey Life'', ''SportsWeek (La Gazetta dello sport)'', ''Canoe Magazine'' and ''Maxim Italy''. She represented [[Chopard]] at [[Cannes Film Festival|The Cannes Films Festival]] in 2012 and 2013 respectively. She co-managed and marketed her then boyfriend [[Sulley Muntari]] brand from 2006 until 2009. In 2012, she became the face of [http://www.printexghana.com/ Printex],{{Cite news|url=https://www.newsghana.com.gh/new-face-of-printex-menaye-donkor-tours-printex-outlets/|title=New face of Printex Menaye Donkor tours Printex outlets|date=27 June 2012|work=News Ghana|access-date=29 September 2017|language=en-US}} a fabric and textiles company in Ghana. Menaye was the ambassador of [[Africa Fashion Week London]] in both 2012 and 2013. She also owns and manages a real estate company in Ghana. == SHE-Y by Menaye == Menaye developed and founded the luxury Italian brand SHE-Y. The brand launched its first all-natural products early in 2016 using ethically-sourced [[Shea butter]] from [[Ghana]]. Her brand plays a part in her charity work by creating more job opportunities in Shea Butter production. A percentage of sales profit of SHE-Y is donated towards Menaye Charity Organization to help educate less fortunate children.{{Cite web|url=http://www.menaye.org/charity/|title=Menaye Donkor Official Website|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} == Philanthropist == Menaye founded the Menaye Charity Organization in 2004 contributing towards the welfare of underprivileged children through providing free quality education in Ghana. Donkor has worked tirelessly for over a decade to improve the lives of women and children in her home country Ghana through the Menaye Charity Organization. The Organisation provides free quality basic education and scholarships to rural underprivileged children in Ghana, health care and the developmental of young girls. She is solely responsible for raising funds to support the organization.{{Cite web|url=https://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/diaspora/Menaye-Donkor-shares-her-passion-for-giving-back-519539|title=Menaye Donkor shares her passion for giving back|website=www.ghanaweb.com|language=en|access-date=29 September 2017}} === The Menaye School of Hope === The school was founded on 7 September 2000 in the central region of [[Ghana]]. Menaye Donkor adopted the school in 2004 after winning Miss Universe Ghana to help build a better environment for the children as the original school lacked in basic necessities. The school is located in Agona Asafo, which is considered one of the most deprived regions of the country, with high poverty and extreme illiteracy rates. Having started with 78 pupils sharing one school block, the school now has over 400 children and three blocks, helping students achieve excellent results in their [[BECE]] (pre-secondary school) examinations. The Menaye Charity Organisation funds everything for the school, from the buildings and equipment to the teachers’ salaries, as well as uniforms, books and stationery. == Awards == In September 2012, Menaye was honored and chosen by the Chief and elders, of Agona Asafo in the Central Region of Ghana, to be the ‘Nkosuohemaa’ or ‘Development Queen’ of Agona Asafo.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/entertainment/Sulley-Muntari-s-Wife-Now-Nkosuohemaa-of-Agona-Asafo-250164|title=Ghana Web|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} Her official title is Nanahemaa Menaye Afumade Afrakoma I. It signifies her global responsibility to her people and as well as her contributions to society. In 2013 she made the list of the 15 Most Influential Africans in Canada,{{Cite web|url=http://entertainment.myjoyonline.com/pages/news/201302/101455.php|title=Joy Online|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} which celebrated individuals who continuously inspire others through great achievements. In 2015, Menaye was honored with the "Woman of The Year" award by the Infant Charity Award in Milan.{{Cite web|url=http://www.vanityfair.it/benessere/salute-e-prevenzione/15/03/19/infant-charity-award-2015|title=VanityFair.it|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} The Infant Charity Award is an organization that recognizes the work of different individuals and associations who support improving the lives of sick children. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * "[http://www.menaye.com/about/ About : Menaye Donkor is a model/actress, entrepreneur and philanthropist]." www.menaye.com. Retrieved 1 April 2014 * "[http://www.modernghana.com/music/21186/3/menaye-charity-organisation-presents-menaye-school.html Menaye Charity Organisation Presents Menaye School of Hope GALA ...‘Together for Hope]." www.modernghana.com. Retrieved 1 April 2014 * "[http://myafrica.allafrica.com/view/people/main/id/0DlF3CxABNZhTEJF.html Menye Donkor]" Retrieved 1 April 2014 * [http://www.vogue.it/en/vogue-black/spotlight-on/2012/05/menaye-donkor Menaye Donkor] at ''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]'' {{Miss Universe 2004 delegates}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Donkor, Menaye}} [[Category:1981 births]] [[Category:Canadian businesspeople]] [[Category:Canadian people of Ghanaian descent]] [[Category:Financial advisors]] [[Category:Footballers' wives and girlfriends]] [[Category:Ghanaian beauty pageant winners]] [[Category:Ghanaian businesspeople]] [[Category:Ghanaian people of Canadian descent]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Miss Universe 2004 contestants]] [[Category:Place of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:York University alumni]]

For multiple names in different languages, use {{lang|[code]|[name]}}. --> | former_name = | type = | industry = | founded = <!-- if known: {{start date|YYYY|MM|DD}} in [[city]], [[country]] --> | founder = <!-- or: | founders = --> | hq_location = [[Abuja]], [[FCT, Nigeria|FCT]], Nigeria | hq_location_city = | hq_location_country = | area_served = <!-- or: | areas_served = --> | key_people = Abubakar Nahuce (Director General) | products = | brands = | services = | owner = <!-- or: | owners = --> | website = <!-- or: | homepage = --><!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> }} Nigerian Telecommunications Limited, or '''NITEL''', was a monopoly telephone service provider in [[Nigeria]] until 1992 when the [[Federal government of Nigeria|Nigerian government]] enacted the [[Nigerian Communications Commission]] act allowing new entrants into the telecommunications sector. During and after its years of monopoly, performance of the firm was sub-par, a behavior similar to other state owned enterprises such as [[Power Holding Company of Nigeria|NEPA]] and government owned water corporations. <ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/183263320|title=Telecommunications research trends|last=Onwumechili|first=Chuka|date=2008|publisher=Nova Science Publishers|others=Ulrich, Hans F., Lehrmann, Ernst P.|year=|isbn=9781604561586|location=New York|pages=144-150|chapter=Chapter 8. Nigeria:Reviving a Former Monopoly in A rapidly Evolving Market|oclc=183263320}}</ref> The firm was formed in 1985 as the welding together of two government entities, the telecoms arm of the Post and Telecommunications (P&T) department under the Ministry of Communications and the Nigerian External Communications (NET)
Looking from 1958 to the arrival of Global Satellite system communication (GSM) in Nigeria; NITEL was able to provide 450,000 subscriber lines for a population of 120 million.<ref>{{cite web|title=Nigeria phone privatisation off|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/7251154.stm|website=BBC News|accessdate=22 October 2014}}</ref>
In February 2008 a report by [[BBC News]] said that the Nigerian government assumed the transnational corporation did not improve performance of NITEL and therefore stopped privatization in favour of [[Transcorp]].{{Citation needed|date=September 2015}} In 2015, the government eventually finalized a transaction that saw NITEL and Mtel's assets to NATCOM.<ref>[http://www.pcworld.com/article/2913072/nigerian-govt-hands-over-nitel-mtel-assets-to-natcom.html "Nigerian gov't hands over Nitel, Mtel assets to NATCOM"], ''PC World'', 21 April 2015. Accessed 3 September 2015.</ref> The deal was valued at $252 million.
Another Nigeria Telecom Company (Ntel) was launched In April which took the place of Nitel, Ntel is the newest reincarnation of the now defunct telecoms company, NITEL. The Nigerian government handed over '''NITEL/Mtel''' assets over to NATCOM (Ntel’s parent company) in a deal worth $252 million last year. In November 2017, Nitel appointed Nate James as vice president of account management.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.channelpartnersonline.com/2017/11/06/nitel-adds-windstream-vet-as-account-management-vp/|title=Nitel Adds Windstream Vet as Account Management VP|website=www.channelpartnersonline.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-12-14}}</ref>
== History ==
=== Post and Telecommunications Department (P&T) === During colonial rule and until 1985, the Post and Telecommunications department provided [[Mail|mailing]] and internal telecommunication services between Nigerian cities while NET provided telecommunications services between selected Nigerian cities and foreign countries. Due to resource constraints, provision of services were planned in phases<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.africa.upenn.edu/ECA/aisi_inftl.html|title=Telecommunications in Nigeria|last=Alabi|first=|date=March 1986|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> with expansion more pronounced between the 1950s and 1970s.
Telegraph services began in the 1880s and was initially managed by the Public Works Department until 1907 when those services were transferred to P & T.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Neusman|first=Dan|date=August 1973|title=Technical Review Supplement. Telecommunications Development in Nigeria|url=|journal=Nigerian Business Digest|volume=|pages=29-35|via=}}</ref> In 1908, a manual telephone exchange with a [[Telephone magneto|magneto switchboard]] of 100 lines was introduced in [[Lagos]] and by 1920 the estimate of telephone lines in the country was 920, at 920. A year later, a multiple [[Telephone switchboard|switchboard]] was introduced with a capacity for 800 lines and in 1941 a [[Point-to-point (telecommunications)|point to point]] connection with a [[teleprinter]] was introduced. In the 1950s, planned investments were launched that included expanding [[Telephone exchange|automatic telephone exchanges]] and [[Trunking|trunk circuits]], launching a Lagos to Port Harcourt [[Microwave transmission|microwave radio transmission]] route and introducing [[Very high frequency|V.H.F]]. multi-channel radio transmission to more cities and towns. In 1961, they were more than 32,000 telephones line and 120 telephone exchanges.<ref name=":2" /> Investments in telecommunications moved the subscriber base to over 100,000 by 1973 and up to 400,000 by 1990.
=== Nigerian External Telecommunications === The history of NET can be traced to [[Colonisation of Africa|colonial rule]] towards the end of the nineteenth century. In 1886, a telegraph service between Lagos and London was provided by African Direct Telegraph Company, this company later became Imperial and International Communications after a merger and then Cable and Wireless. Upon independence, the government of Nigerian decided to go into a partnership with [[Cable & Wireless plc|Cable and Wireless]], acquiring interest in the Nigerian arm of Cable and Wireless, and renaming the company Nigerian External Telecommunications.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=June 1982|title=NET Today|url=|journal=Nigerian Enterprises|volume=2|pages=9-12|via=}}</ref> The new firm provided international telephone, telex and telegraph services, high speed data transmission and transmission and reception of real time television but those services were mainly restricted to Lagos and major cities of Nigeria such as [[Ibadan]], [[Enugu]], [[Kaduna]], and [[Port Harcourt|Port-Harcourt]]. The firm's major investment was in building a HF transmission and receiving station.<ref name=":3" />
The firm began providing [[Telex|automatic telex service]] in 1971 and In 1980, NET introduced [[International direct dialing|international Direct Dialing]] and faster telex services between Nigeria and select Western countries. NET also offered private leased telegraph services with annual subscription fees to companies and managed television events transmitted or received via satellite such as [[FESTAC 77]] and sporting events.<ref name=":3" /> For much of its existence, NET's facilities were inadequate compared to the needs of the business and wider population, man times the lines were congested as available lines on the telephone trunks could not keep up with the traffic.
=== NITEL === Nigerian Telecommunications Limited was formed in 1985 as the combination of the telecommunications division of Post and Telecommunications and NET. The new company was formed to improve coordination of telecommunication services within the country, to make internal communications more commercial in objective and to reduce duplication of budgetary allocations and investments.<ref name=":1" /> NITEL inherited mostly [[Analog signal|analogue]] infrastructure from its predecessors and had to fund new investments in digital infrastructures.<ref name=":1" /> It introduced [[mobile telephony]] in 1992, through MTS, a partnership with Digital Communications Limited, an Atlanta based firm. However, operationally, it was still inefficient, the lines were [[Network congestion|congested]], the billing system was inefficient and the call completion rate for long distance calls was below 50%.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Jerome|first=Afeikhena|date=March 2002|title=Public enterprise reform in Nigeria: Evidence from the telecommunications industry|url=https://ideas.repec.org/p/aer/rpaper/rp_129.html|journal=African Economic Research Consortium|language=en|volume=Paper 129|pages=|via=}}</ref> When new private telephone services emerged in Lagos during the 1990s, many of them depended on an unreliable NITEL for inter-connectivity services.<ref name=":0" /> In addition, demand for services in some cities was much higher than the capacity of NITEL while many NITEL lines were inoperative due to lack of maintenance of infrastructure or inadequate supporting cable network infrastructure.<ref>{{Cite news|url=|title=Nitel, a Poor Advertisement for Nigeria|last=Keeling|first=William|date=April 19, 1990|work=The Financial Times|access-date=}}</ref>
In 2002, MTEL which had acquired the assets of MTS, obtained a [[GSM]] license.
Beginning in 2001, the company went through a period of botched sales and divestment, the first was the proposed sale of 51% stake to a group of investors under the trading name of Investors International London limited, the sale was cancelled after the investors failed to make the final bid price. Subsequently, the government stopped capital investment in the firm and approved a management turnaround contract with a firm called Pentascope in 2003. The contract was cancelled in 2005 after it became clear Pentascope did not have the adequate resources to run NITEL. Another failed divestment to Orascom in 2005 followed before the firm was sold to a subsidiary of [[Transnational Corporation of Nigeria|Transcorp]] in 2007, but that sale was revoked in 2009. In 2014, the firm was sold to NATCOM, a group of investors led by [[John Olatunde Ayeni|Tunde Ayeni]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://allafrica.com/stories/201505180726.html|title=Turning Around the Fortunes of Nitel|last=Edeki|first=Emmanuel|date=May 17, 2015|work=Daily Independent|access-date=}}</ref>

'''Newton Glassman''' is the founder and managing partner of [[Catalyst Capital Group]], the second largest [[private equity]] firm in [[Canada]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|title = Irascible Newton Glassman's coming of age is all part of the plan|url = http://business.financialpost.com/news/fp-street/irascible-newton-glassmans-coming-of-age-is-all-part-of-the-plan|website = Financial Post|accessdate = 2015-11-18|date = September 27, 2014|last = Tedesco|first = Theresa}}</ref>
== Career == Glassman received an undergraduate and law degree at the [[University of Toronto]]. He then attended business school at [[Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania]], and graduated with an [[MBA]] in 1990.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|title = Newton Glassman, a private man in the stressful world of private equity|url = https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/careers/careers-leadership/newton-glassman-a-private-man-in-the-stressful-world-of-private-equity/article15807246/?page=all|website = The Globe and Mail|publisher = |accessdate = 2015-11-18}}</ref> After graduating he joined Canadian Corporate Funding Ltd., then one of Canada's leading private equity firms.<ref name=":1" /> He later joined [[Cerberus Capital Management]].<ref name=":1" />
=== Catalyst Capital Group === Glassman founded Catalyst Capital Group in 2002 along with Gabriel de Alba.<ref name=":1" /> The firm specializes in purchasing distressed assets and corporate restructurings.<ref name=":1" /> Catalyst has been involved in deals involving [[Gateway Casinos]], [[Canwest]], and [[Mobilicity]].<ref name=":0" /> By 2014, the firm was Canada's second largest private equity firm.<ref name=":0" /> In 2015, Glassman was involved in a feud with Greg Boland over a negative research report about Callidus Capital Corp, which Glassman's firm held a controlling stake in.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|title = Feud Between Canadian Fund Managers Escalates With Call for Public Debate|url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/feud-between-canadian-fund-managers-escalates-with-call-for-public-debate-1443755170|newspaper = Wall Street Journal|access-date = 2015-11-18|issn = 0099-9660|first = Ben|last = Dummett}}</ref> The two firms were in litigation after Boland's first West Face Capital Inc. hired an analyst from Catalyst.<ref name=":2" />
Glassman developed a reputation as being publicity shy and "combative" in financial circles.<ref name=":0" /> He has been called a "pit bull negotiator."<ref>{{Cite web|title = 5 Big Questions for Ryan Kavanaugh's Troubled Relativity Studio|url = http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/5-big-questions-ryan-kavanaughs-808665|website = The Hollywood Reporter|accessdate = 2015-11-18}}</ref>
Glassman donated $2.5 million to the [[University of Western Ontario|University of Western Ontario's]] faculty of law as part of a $10 million plan to fund programs on insolvency and restructuring.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Newton Glassman sets out to reform Canadian insolvency law, one law student at a time|url = http://business.financialpost.com/news/fp-street/newton-glassman-sets-out-to-reform-canadian-insolvency-law-one-law-student-at-a-time|website = Financial Post|accessdate = 2015-11-18}}</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
==External links== [http://www.catcapital.com/ Catalyst Capital Group]

'''Overhoff Technology Corp''' is a subsidiary of [[US Nuclear Corp]], (OTC BB: UCLE) based in [[Milford, Ohio]] that designs, constructs, and sells [[radiation monitoring]] equipment. Their product line includes [[tritium]] monitors (an Overhoff specialty), [[heavy water]] leak detectors, [[Gamma ray|gamma]] survey meters, environmental ion chambers and [[neutron]] [[dosimeter]]s which are used to detect radioactive tritium in air, water and ground sources.
Overhoff Technology's products are [[ISO 9001]] certified and used globally for [[nuclear power plant]]s, fusion energy research, development of new pharmaceuticals, defense industries, and research facilities. The Company has been awarded contracts by the [[United States Department of Defense]]<ref>[http://www.governmentcontractswon.com/department/defense/overhoff_technology_corporatio_072875339.asp Government Contracts]</ref> and sells tritium equipment to China, South Korean, Canada, UK and Argentina based nuclear power facilities.
Overhoff Technology Corp was founded by [[Mario Overhoff]] (1928-2005). The Company was acquired by [[Optron Scientific]] Corp/Technical Associates in 2006 and operates under US Nuclear Corp. The Company became publicly traded in early 2015 and trades on the [[Over-the-Counter Bulletin Board]] under the trading symbol: UCLE

'''Rolf Ketil Bjørn''' (18 January 1938 – 24 November 2008) was a Norwegian businessperson and politician for the [[Socialist Left Party (Norway)|Socialist Left Party]].
Bjørn was born in [[Gáivuotna – Kåfjord|Kåfjord]] as the son of director Rolf Bjørn (1906–2000) and housewife Mariane Malvik (1908–1993). He finished his secondary education in 1957, and eventually enrolled at the [[Norwegian School of Management]]. He worked in the private company ''Gustaf Aspelin'' from 1964 to 1962, and in the family business ''Ric Bjørn'' from 1964 to 1989.<ref name=bio>{{stortingetbio|RKB}}</ref> Despite his social background in the [[petite bourgeoisie]], he became a member of left-wing political groups. For this, he earned the nickname "the red millionaire".<ref name=nordlys>{{cite news|url=http://www.nordlys.no/nyheter/article3944919.ece|title=Rolf Ketil Bjørn 1938-2008 (obituary)|last=Fjellheim|first=Skjalg|date=25 November 2008|work=Nordlys|language=Norwegian|accessdate=7 December 2008}}</ref> From 1959 to 1964 he was a member of the secretariat of the [[Young Communist League of Norway]], having chaired the local branch in [[Tromsø]] from 1952 to 1957. From 1966 he held local leadership in the [[Socialist People's Party (Norway)|Socialist People's Party]], which later became the [[Socialist Left Party (Norway)|Socialist Left Party]].<ref name=bio/> He opposed Norwegian membership in the [[European Union]] and [[NATO]]. Nonetheless, he did favor cooperation with the social democratic [[Norwegian Labour Party|Labour Party]], both locally as well as in the national [[Red-Green Coalition (Norway)|Red-Green Coalition]].<ref name=nordlys/>
He was elected to serve in Tromsø [[municipal council (Norway)|municipal council]] in 1987. Halfway through the term, in [[Norwegian parliamentary election, 1989|1989]], he was elected to represent [[Troms (constituency)|Troms]] in the [[Storting|Norwegian Parliament]]. He was re-elected in [[Norwegian parliamentary election, 1993|1993]] for a second, but final term. After this he served more terms in the municipal council.<ref name=bio/> He finally retired in 2007.<ref name=nordlys/>
Bjørn was married, and had three children. He died in November 2008, at the [[University Hospital of North Norway]], of cancer.<ref name=nordlys/>

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2013}} '''Selective disclosure''' is a situation when a publicly traded company discloses material information to a single person, or a limited group of people or investors, as opposed to disclosing the information to all investors at the same time.
[[Material information]] is roughly defined as information that would cause a reasonable investor to make a buy or sell decision.
A problem with selective disclosure that the [[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]] (SEC) sought to eliminate with [[Regulation Fair Disclosure]](a.k.a. [[Regulation FD]] or [[Reg FD]]), is that it creates an uneven playing field for investors, allowing some investors to profit from material [[market moving information]] before others.
An example of a selective disclosure could go as follows: A company insider tells a small group of Wall Street analysts that the company is going to beat current analyst consensus estimates for earnings per share. If this is the first time the company disclosed such [[earnings guidance|guidance]], and the guidance wasn't simultaneously disseminated to all investors via a press release or publicized webcast, then the disclosure would constitute selective disclosure.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Selective Disclosure}} [[Category:Financial regulation]]

'''Sindh Industrial Trading Estates (Guarantee) Limited''', also called ''S. I. T. E. Limited'' or simply ''SITE'', is a government-guaranteed-company established in November 1947 by the [[Government of Sindh]] in [[Karachi]] and later in other major cities of this province of Pakistan. In 2012, SITE located in Karachi still claimed to be one of the largest industrial estates in Asia due to its huge land size that is spread over 4,460 acres.<ref name=Dawn/>
==History== In order to promote industrialization and create attractive conditions for industrialists, Government of Sindh established ''Sindh Industrial Trading Estates'', in the year 1947. The object was to establish planned industrial areas where industrialists, in the future, could have all their required and needed facilities such as land, road, railway, water supply, electricity, gas, telephone, godowns (warehouses), sanitation, drainage, residential areas for workers and other necessary public amenities. These facilities were designed to create an industrial environment congenial for intending future industrialists.<ref name=BR/>
==Organizational structure== S.I.T.E established by virtue of policy decision through Sindh Government No.24-I.B/47.1, dated June 2, 1947. SITE is the Government department under [[Ministry of Commerce and Industry]], [[Government of Sindh]] in Pakistan. The Company works through Board of Directors appointed by Government of Sindh and is accountable to the provincial government for its performance.<ref>[https://dailytimes.com.pk/78466/anti-corruption-dept-gears-up-probe-against-400-illegal-appointments-in-site/ Anti-Corruption Department gears up probe against 400 illegal appointments in SITE] Daily Times (newspaper), Published 2 June 2016, Retrieved 10 November 2017</ref> It is also a non-profit organization of Pakistan.<ref name=BR>[http://fp.brecorder.com/2005/12/20051202359897/ Sindh Industrial and Trading Estate Limited past and present] Business Recorder (newspaper), Published 2 December 2005, Retrieved 11 November 2017</ref>
There are a total of 10 industrial estates, each one of them called SITE, located in Karachi, Sindh and in other major cities of the province. Sindh Industrial and Trading Estate zone is providing employment to more than 1/2 million people.<ref name=BR/><ref name=Dawn1/> The objective and aim is to boost the industrialization in the province of Sindh.<ref name=BR/>

==Companies located within SITE area== * ''Valika Textile Mills'' was the first to locate here in 1947 and the [[Founder of Pakistan|founder of Pakistan]] [[Muhammad Ali Jinnah]] was asked to lay the foundation stone of it.<ref name=BR/>
* One of the international companies, for example, located at SITE Karachi is ''Exide Pakistan Limited'' which manufactures and markets automotive batteries.<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/finance/stocks/overview/EXID.KA Company Profile and stock quote of Exide Pakistan Limited on Reuters.com business website] Retrieved 10 November 2017</ref> * Many other companies located here represent business sectors such as food products, chemicals, heavy and light engineering workshops, plastic, rubber, leather products, repair and maintenance of motor vehicles and their assembly, woodworking, glass products and storage warehouses.<ref name=BR/>
